docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 Iran Pursues Nuclear Work; Fight Inside U.N. Is Possible Iran has drastically curtailed cooperation with international inspectors over the past month as it has sped forward with its nuclear fuel enrichment activities, the inspectors said. In pursuing the work, Iran has set up a struggle among United Nations Security Council members about how to respond. A1 Food Aid for Darfur to Be Cut The World Food Program, the United Nations agency responsible for feeding three million people affected by the conflict in Darfur, announced that it would cut in half the amount of food it distributed there because it was short of money. A3 Mexico to Ease Drug Laws Mexican lawmakers passed a sweeping drug law that would crack down on small-time dealers, legalize possession of small quantities of drugs, including heroin and cocaine, and mandate treatment for addicts. A3 U.S. Death Rate in Iraq Rises The military announced the death of an American soldier in Iraq, bringing April's toll so far to 69, the highest in five months, and disrupting a trend of falling American fatalities that had begun in November. A7 The number of insurgent attacks on civilians in Iraq skyrocketed last year, resulting in almost 8,300 deaths and accounting for more than 50 percent of those killed in terrorist attacks worldwide, according to a State Department report. A7 Poland Signs Coalition Deal The governing party in Poland, in what many see as a last-ditch effort to construct a working majority, announced that it had signed a coalition agreement with a populist party that would make one of the country's leading anti-European Union activists the deputy prime minister. A7 For China, Spending in Asia An array of projects that China is developing in Indonesia follow a $7 billion investment spree last year, illustrating the symbiotic relationship between China's need for a variety of raw materials and its Asian neighbors' readiness to provide them, often at enormous environmental cost. A1 NATIONAL A8-9; 12 President Says No To Anthem in Spanish While President Bush has tried to maintain a middle ground in the hot debate over immigration, he signaled that he stands with conservatives on a cultural dividing point: the Spanish version of the national anthem, a new touchstone of the immigrants-rights movement. Mr. Bush said immigrants should learn the English version. A1 Drug Market Domination The Bush administration said that two drug companies have captured nearly half of the vast new market for prescription drug insurance under Medicare, providing a glimpse of a business that has been plagued by start-up problems but could be a profitable and fast-growing venture for insurers. A8 Letter Fuels Families' Ire Two days after receiving a letter from Randal McCloy Jr., the only survivor of the Sago mine disaster, victims' families said they felt a renewed sense of outrage, while relatives of miners said they feared that the hazards persisted. A8 Scandal Imperils G.O.P. Bids Representative Richard W. Pombo, a California Republican who faces re-election this year, is battling intense scrutiny over his relationships with Jack Abramoff and Tom DeLay, signaling the wide impact of the lobbying scandal on G.O.P. futures in Congress. A8 Rush Limbaugh Surrenders Rush Limbaugh, the conservative talk-radio host, was charged with prescription drug fraud and turned himself over to Florida authorities as part of a deal to resolve a lengthy inquiry into whether he improperly obtained painkillers. A12 SCIENCE/HEALTH Shuttle to Fly Without All Fixes NASA officials said they will launch the space shuttle Discovery in July without making all modifications to its fuel tank that might reduce foam debris, which has been a priority for the space agency since the shuttle Columbia's destruction in 2003. A9 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 False Rumors of Raids Send Immigrants Hiding False rumors of random federal immigration raids have sparked panic in immigrant communities around the country, sending thousands of people into hiding. Towns in New Jersey and on Long Island have been among those most affected by the fear, advocates and officials say. B1 Union Leader Leaves Jail Roger Toussaint, the president of the transit workers' union, sounded as defiant as ever after walking out of jail, having served nearly four days of his 10-day sentence for leading an illegal strike. B1 Ground Zero Dust and Illness A doctor overseeing a federal effort to determine the health impact of exposure to ground zero dust said anecdotal evidence suggested that breathing in the smoke and ash that hung over the area after the collapse of the towers could lead to illness. But he said that a rigorous scientific study was required. B3 Beliefs B5 SPORTSSATURDAY D1-7 Texans Have Deal With Top Pick The Houston Texans threw the National Football League draft into tumult by signing defensive end Mario Williams to make him the draft's first overall pick and passing on Heisman Trophy winning running back Reggie Bush. D1 OBITUARIES C10 Steve Howe The relief pitcher whose promising career was derailed by cocaine and alcohol abuse, he was 48. C10 ARTS B7-17 O'Donnell to Join 'The View' With Barbara Walters at her side, Rosie O'Donnell told a live, national television audience that she would return to daytime television this September alongside Ms. Walters as a co-host of ''The View'' on ABC. A13 BUSINESS DAY C1-9 Crude Oil a Financial Asset Crude oil is not merely a physical commodity that fuels the world economy, more and more it has also become a valuable financial asset, bought and sold in electronic exchanges by traders around the world. And they too, have helped push prices higher. A1 Pfizer Promotes Celebrex Despite the increased heart attack risks, Pfizer, the world's largest drug maker, has resumed advertising the painkiller Celebrex. The ad campaign has raised the ire of consumer groups, who say that Celebrex is so dangerous that Pfizer should stop selling it. C1 Law Firm in Spotlight The six-year investigation into whether lawyers at Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman used illegal tactics, took a significant turn after Howard J. Vogel, a retired real estate mortgage broker, agreed to plead guilty and cooperate in the investigation. C1 U.S. Economy Surges Propelled by consumer spending and business investment, the nation's gross domestic product surged by 4.8 percent in the first quarter of the year, fastest rate of growth since 2003. C3 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A10-11 Editorials: The sleeping giant; where America leads; still battering the Katrina homeless; Verlyn Klinkenborg on the Morgan Library. Columns: Maureen Dowd, John Tierney. Bridge B8 Crossword B15 TV Listings B17 Weather B18
